Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of MIRTH: A Novel Catheter-Based Intramyocardial Ventricular Remodeling Procedure

Background: MIRTH is a novel catheter-based intramyocardial ventricular remodeling procedure aimed at reducing left ventricular chamber dimensions and wall stress, thereby improving cardiac performance in cardiomyopathic animals.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted on juvenile Yorkshire swine with either healthy myocardium or ischemic cardiomyopathy. Animals were randomly assigned to receive the MIRTH intervention or serve as controls. The primary outcome was the change in left ventricular performance, assessed by contractility and mechanical efficiency, over a 90-day period. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed with sealed envelopes. Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not applicable.

Results: A total of 33 animals were randomised: 17 with healthy myocardium and 16 with ischemic cardiomyopathy. MIRTH significantly improved left ventricular performance in cardiomyopathic animals, with increased contractility and mechanical efficiency (p < 0.05). In healthy animals, MIRTH resulted in a 6% increase in ejection fraction (p = 0.045). No adverse events related to myocardial erosion were observed, although two early implants failed due to suture abrasion, leading to a change to ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene suture. Nine of 12 healthy animals survived to 90 days, with two deaths attributed to unrelated bacterial sepsis.

Interpretation: MIRTH demonstrates significant improvements in cardiac performance in cardiomyopathic swine, offering a promising approach to ventricular remodeling. The procedure's safety and efficacy warrant further investigation in clinical settings.

Trial registration: Not provided.
